title: Bypass rate limiting on /users/password (possibly site-wide rate limit bypass?)

profile.name: HackerOne
profile.about: Vulnerability disclosure should be safe, transparent, and rewarding.

vulnerability_information:
Hi there,

I noticed when we hit the /users_sign_in endpoint too many times it will give us 

`````
HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 01:52:19 GMT
Content-Type: text/plain
`````

However, this can be "reset" although I struggle to get it to work EVERYTIME on /users/sign_in. This however, does work all the time on /users/password endpoint hence why i'm reporting so maybe you can investigate further on the /users_sign_in endpoint.

If we send the following POST:

`````
POST /users/password HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 206
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Origin: https://hackerone.com
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/52.0.2743.116 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
DNT: 1
Referer: https://hackerone.com/users/password/new
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: en-GB,en-US;q=0.8,en;q=0.6
Cookie: cookies_here

authenticity_token=your_token_here&utf8=%E2%9C%93&user%5Bemail%5D=email@here.com&commit=Send
`````

Now send the request around ~10 times and it'll hit "Too Many Requests". Now simply add %00 on the end of the email and resend even more password reset emails. 

&user%5Bemail%5D=email@here.com%00 - and keep adding %00 everytime you are rate limited. After a while you can go back to just %00 as it resets after so long.

I tried this on the /users/sign_in endpoint like I said and was successful for about ~50 login attempts before it just died and kept giving me a Precondition error each time (I wonder if I need to change auth_token every few requests?). I'm going to keep investigating in the morning.

No real impact with just mass emailing someone a reset password link, but I thought it was worth reporting because the rate limiting bypass might exist in other areas (with the use of the null byte %00)

{F121260}
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi there,

I noticed when we hit the /users_sign_in endpoint too many times it will give us 

HTTP/1.1 429 Too Many Requests
Date: Mon, 19 Sep 2016 01:52:19 GMT
Content-Type: text/plain

However, this can be "reset" although I struggle to get it to work EVERYTIME on /users/sign_in. This however, does work all the time on /users/password endpoint hence why i'm reporting so maybe you can investigate further on the /users_sign_in endpoint.

If we send the following POST:

POST /users/password HTTP/1.1
Host: hackerone.com
Connection: close
Content-Length: 206
Cache-Control: max-age=0
Origin: https://hackerone.com
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/52.0.2743.116 Safari/537.36
Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
DNT: 1
Referer: https://hackerone.com/users/password/new
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: en-GB,en-US;q=0.8,en;q=0.6
Cookie: cookies_here

authenticity_token=your_token_here&utf8=%E2%9C%93&user%5Bemail%5D=email@here.com&commit=Send

Now send the request around ~10 times and it'll hit "Too Many Requests". Now simply add %00 on the end of the email and resend even more password reset emails.

&user%5Bemail%5D=email@here.com%00 - and keep adding %00 everytime you are rate limited. After a while you can go back to just %00 as it resets after so long.

I tried this on the /users/sign_in endpoint like I said and was successful for about ~50 login attempts before it just died and kept giving me a Precondition error each time (I wonder if I need to change auth_token every few requests?). I'm going to keep investigating in the morning.

No real impact with just mass emailing someone a reset password link, but I thought it was worth reporting because the rate limiting bypass might exist in other areas (with the use of the null byte %00)

activities.message:
hey @zseano,

Please note that we explicitly exclude automated email spamming from our security scope on @security:
> ## Scope Exclusions
> [..]
> Spamming other users with automated HackerOne emails or notifications (e.g. abusing the forgot password form).

We rate limit our sign-in endpoint a lot more harshly than we do our password reset, since there is no harm in being able to send a bunch of emails to somebody (I mean, it's annoying, but you could also just... send them a bunch of emails). 

I haven't been able to find out any feasible attack scenario here, It doesn't look like this is circumventing any measures we have in place.

Dirk
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Understood, but I think you missed why I reported this. Using %00 in signing in can bypass the rate limiting, and I said although I was having issues with it id reinvestigate in the morning... But hey ho.
activities.markdown_message: Understood, but I think you missed why I reported this. Using %00 in signing in can bypass the rate limiting, and I said although I was having issues with it id reinvestigate in the morning... But hey ho.

activities.message:
@zseano Ah, that makes sense! I've been able to reproduce the issue you described, and it appears it has something to do with the way we rate-limit folks. 

I'll take a look if this impacts any other endpoints, but it looks like this is only an issue on `POST /users/password`, which would mean the only issue is mail spamming, but if we decide to change something here to resolve it, I'll at least close the report as `informative`. 

Thanks for your patience and understanding
Dirk
activities.markdown_message:
@zseano Ah, that makes sense! I've been able to reproduce the issue you described, and it appears it has something to do with the way we rate-limit folks.

I'll take a look if this impacts any other endpoints, but it looks like this is only an issue on POST /users/password, which would mean the only issue is mail spamming, but if we decide to change something here to resolve it, I'll at least close the report as informative.

Thanks for your patience and understanding
Dirk

Kind regards,
Dirk

activities.message:
Can confirm using %00 over and over is fixed.. but we can now use %0d%0a and achieve same results by increasing %0d%0a when we hit "Too many requests".

http://puu.sh/rjoeu/c788e81eec.png
activities.markdown_message:

activities.message: Curses! * *shakes fist* *. I Checked for a number of non-printing chars (e.g. backspace won't work), but it didn't occur to me that a CRLF might circumvent it, thanks for pointing that out! We'll get back to you asap with a more robust fix!

Apologies for the long wait, we had a high-prio security issue come up last week, so our security efforts were focussed on that. We'll get back to this issue as soon as that's resolved!

Kind regards, and thanks for you patience,
Dirk

activities.message:
Hi Sean, 

We haven't forgotten about you. 

I love how you honour your profile description: //"I like to try break things."// You did well here.

We like to fix things. In a proper way. So needing a bit more time to resolve this issue.

We'll keep you posted.

Tom

activities.message:
Hi Sean,

We've released a patch on the `/users/password` endpoint. Can you try breaking it again?

It seems that only this endpoint was affected though and indeed as you state earlier there is no real impact besides mass mailing a user. Note that you can also do that by just sending a lot of emails yourself to an email address :)

Or are there any other attack scenarios you can come up with?
activities.markdown_message:
Hi Sean,

We've released a patch on the /users/password endpoint. Can you try breaking it again?

It seems that only this endpoint was affected though and indeed as you state earlier there is no real impact besides mass mailing a user. Note that you can also do that by just sending a lot of emails yourself to an email address :)

Or are there any other attack scenarios you can come up with?

activities.message:
Hi Tom,

Totally forgot about this, I read the email after just waking up the other day haha, sorry! 

So I retested and it seems we can still use %09 over and over again to bypass the rate limit, so nope.. not fixed yet. :P

`````
authenticity_token=xLSs%2FW7Sjlhvyi3YhZxuxEsqGdgCdK2E07Azn%2FhpAUo7%2B9lMKMqfNY0UZZW9NpCI4jYlf0kunkpoJOzIrddMaA%3D%3D&utf8=%E2%9C%93&user%5Bemail%5D=sean.roesner%40googlemail.com%09%09%09&commit=Send
`````

Attack scenario? Hmm.. I don't know too much about how email blacklisting works on things like gmail etc and I also don't know what you use for your mail server, but I wonder what would happen if we used a multi-threaded script to mass-reset password emails? If your mail server is churning out a ton of emails a minute what would happen? 

You know more about H1's setup, so perhaps you can enlighten me  as i'm generally curious what's the worst someone can do with causing a mail server to mass send emails.. :P

activities.message:
Hey @zseano,

Sorry for the delay. Based on my understanding and investigation you were able to bypass the rate limiting for same email address. Looking at your most recent case, adding `%09` onto the end of the email would not be targeting the same email-did you get reset password emails for those requests?

Thanks for the clarification,
@bencode
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @zseano,

Sorry for the delay. Based on my understanding and investigation you were able to bypass the rate limiting for same email address. Looking at your most recent case, adding %09 onto the end of the email would not be targeting the same email-did you get reset password emails for those requests?

Thanks for the clarification,
@bencode

activities.message:
Incorrect @bencode. Using %09 will still target the same email. %09 is a blank space, so using the following:

`````
authenticity_token=token&utf8=%E2%9C%93&user%5Bemail%5D=test%40googlemail.com%09%09&commit=Send
`````

Wil send an email to test@googlemail.com. You can bypass the rate limit by appending %09 over and over.
activities.markdown_message:
Incorrect @bencode. Using %09 will still target the same email. %09 is a blank space, so using the following:

authenticity_token=token&utf8=%E2%9C%93&user%5Bemail%5D=test%40googlemail.com%09%09&commit=Send

Wil send an email to test@googlemail.com. You can bypass the rate limit by appending %09 over and over.

@zseano yep you are right, I've also reproduced with burpsuite. I'll work on a fix and get back to you when we've released it.

Thanks,
@bencode

activities.message:
Hey @zseano,

We have pushed out a fix for this. The blank space characters that are ignored when sending the reset password email will also be ignored when rate limiting. Can you verify this works for you?

Thanks,
@bencode
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @zseano,

We have pushed out a fix for this. The blank space characters that are ignored when sending the reset password email will also be ignored when rate limiting. Can you verify this works for you?

Thanks,
@bencode

activities.message: Yup I can confirm it's fixed this time. I hit the rate limit, appended blank chars (%09, %00 etc) and the rate limit still occurs. Great job guys :)
activities.markdown_message: Yup I can confirm it's fixed this time. I hit the rate limit, appended blank chars (%09, %00 etc) and the rate limit still occurs. Great job guys :)

activities.message:
Hey @zseano,

Even though the issue is technically out of scope, since the only affected endpoint did nothing but send an email, it was only a matter of time before we would have used the same logic in other endpoints and made ourselves vulnerable to all kinds of malicious rate-limiting shenanigans. That's why we're considering this report in-scope regardless.

We want to thank you for making HackerOne safer, for all the effort you put in to make sure this issue was thoroughly resolved, and your patience in this matter.

activities.message:
@zseano,

While this is something that's out-of-scope, we appreciate your work here in helping us get our rate limiting implementation in better shape, so we're awarding a $500 bonus plus swag.

Thanks again for going back and forth on this. Appreciate the assistance!

Happy hacking. :)
